column1: How many homicides will there be in Chicago, IL, in 2020?
column6: ['Society', 'Health']

I am convinced by the argumentation of @Terry-Smith which is also based on data from past years. There are currently 787 cases according to https://heyjackass.com/# which gives more and more weight to the argument of Terry-Smith. There are less than 3 days left. This year there were 2.17 deaths/day on average. There is a high probability that the figure will remain below 795.
Moving up to the 100, given now close to the end of the year.
No change; I'm going to remain here until the end. In particular, I'm giving 5% to deaths in Christmas+New Year+backlog of deaths. Not my proudest question.
My original estimate of between 736 and 795 appears to have been right as 744 have been killed and there only two weeks left.
Still confused that https://heyjackass.com/ is showing a different number
Two weeks to go in the year, we stand at 727 so far. Barring a major incident I can't see the number moving above 795

Cook County data counts 24 more Chicago homicides as of Dec 8 than does the Tribune. If the Tribune later choose to include those 24, thereâ€™s still a chance (18%ish) of passing 795. So my 1% is for the possibility they retrospectively fix their count.
source ABC7chicago.com has over 700 as of December 1, 2020
According to heyjackass.com a person is shot every 11 h. [1] This means end of october there will be 755 + (16 (days left in october) * 24 h/day / 11 homicides / h) = 790.
At 735 today, so less than 736 seems impossible. according to the slider on the Chicago Tribune link, there is still 20 fewer deaths than in 2016 when it went to 795, so also very unlikely.
31 days left, 719 so far. Carrying on at same rate 2.2 a day would give us 787 still in bracket 3

Unfortunately, the Chicago website has not updated since Nov 9th, however we were on track to decline relative to 2016, which represented the 4th bin - thus placing the final outcome in the 3rd bin [1]
Deaths are 21 less than the year it hit 795. With the number of days left this year getting lower, it may be time to go all in on 736-795.
Looks like the numbers are slightly down, with a 20 homicide gap between the highest year and this year.

On the latest update of November 9th, the Tribune showed 673 homicides although the actual number through that date according to the City of Chicago was 688. Maybe there's some difference in definition (I didn't look at every entry in the csv file and compare it to the Tribune page), but in any case "Fewer than 676" has to be 0% in a city that size, unless the Tribune never updates that page again and the GJOpen simply expires this question.

Very frustrating that the Chicago Tribune, the official source for this question, has not updated their Daily Homicide Update site since November 9th, and that their totals through the 9th have a 2 digit difference from those reported in other sources.
Out of curiosity I checked the wounded totals. But for poor marksmanship this forecast would be well over 1200 already .

Exceptional 2020 year, with significant more events since covid months. Using 10 years historical figures, we see a similar behavior to 2016, which possibly slowing down faster. Using ratios of months 1-10 to 11-12, gives significant chances to the top band (unfortunately). So here pretty much a quantitative forecast using time series and seasonality though pure ETS forecast is showing significant variance, such that we put caution on the outputs there.
Is it me, or the page (https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/breaking/ct-chicago-homicides-data-tracker-htmlstory.html) hasn't updated in a while?
https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/breaking/ct-chicago-shootings-violence-20201121-nbndamlzgra2don4rdddlajzhy-story.html
The rate appears to be slowing, and is already a full 10 homicides behind the year it went over 795. It looks as though it will be somewhere in the 736-795 range.

It's getting cold in Chicago, so the season's about over. Without going to the trouble of actually checking statistics, my recollection from my Illinois years is that the rate of most crimes, including homicide, always went down when it got cold in Chicago. You might kill people you live with during a Chicago winter, but activities for which you have to leave the house, including muggings and armed robberies and street fights, used to decline reliably starting about now. Can't think of a reason that would change.
Balancing out for 1 week

Running Bayes gives me 26% for the third bin and 74% for the fourth bin.... Obviously, I swung pretty hard into the third bin after last week's data drop from the Chicago Tribune. The total deaths between Jan and end of October came to 673. If we hit 795 then 2020 will be the only year to do so when the totals through October are 673. The next closest was 1989 when the total through October was 677..... so, I have to conclude that I'm either doing Bayes incorrectly, that there is something I don't understand about the formula, or some other error on my part.... maybe data from November will radically change my opinion....

On track for 785, with around 2.15 homicides occurring each day. This is firmly within the 736-795 and above both historical averages and the 2016 total (the track for which the 2020 curve is currently hugging), meaning that this number is more likely to go down than up without extenuating circumstances increasing the daily numbers by about 10% for the next 50 or so days.
Rate has dropped off and we are past the time of the year that typically sees the greatest increase.
Have looked at a lot of data a lot of different ways. Basically my view is that the underlying factors that caused the homicide rate to jump in June are still with us and not going away this year.
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1174044
Reran simulation using data updated through 10-24. Result is a forecast mean of 787 with 29% of forecasts coming in over 795. That is up 4% >795 from the week before.
68 in October
For the last 2 months of 2020: Bin 1 = <11/month Bin 2 = 11 - <40/month Bin 3 = 40 - <70/month Bin 4 = 70 or more/month
Current trajectory: 777. With just over 2 months to go, this is almost definitely going to end up in the 736-795 bucket.
I explain this forecast with fancy charts on my new blog: https://theclyborthcorporation.wordpress.com/2020-chicago-homicides-forecast-2/
Giving more deference to the aggregate.
On track to surpass 795 if rates do not slow down. Historically, the rates stay consistent throughout the year, steadily rising until the end of the year.

The slope is definitely higher than usual over the last several months. If the slope flattens out there's a slim chance it drops under 735. If it continues at the same pace the remainder of the year it would put it over 795. I'd guess it flattens out a bit making 736 to 795 most likely, but that's just based on the slope of most of the years and this one could easily be different (and already has been much different than previous years).

According to heyjackass.com a person is shot every 10:54 h. [1] This means end of october there will be 653 + (7 (days left in october) * 24 h/day / 10,9 homicides / h) = 653 + 15 = 668. In 2011 84% of homicides happened until end of october. [2] Assuming the same distribution in 2020 we are heading for 668 / 0.84 = 795 homicides in 2020.
Updating on new data.
Updated numbers though Oct 18 increase likelihood of ending the year above 795.
I based my prediction is based on the number of reported homicides as of Oct 9and factorerd the average month homicide rate and then made allowances for the trending increase.

605 recorded homicides this year means we are on pace to hit 761 by year's end. That's 18 less than 2 weeks ago, showing that the total is beginning to regress towards the mean. We also continue to hug the curve of 2016, which led to an eventual 762 deaths, so this projection makes even more sense.
Updated numbers for the second week of October.
Higher than 2016 this week, though barely.
I underestimated ability of Chicagoans to kill one another.
On pace to 768.
Recalculated using the 8 deaths that have occurred in October so far. I anticipate that the 4th bin will increase as more data for October comes in.
Slight uptick in probability favoring the 4th bin given how we finished September.

Skewing a bit toward the higher end. So far it's been matching 2017. Whether it hits the upward jog in November that 2017 did is the biggest question. Looking at most of the previous years the slope is lower in winter, so I would expect that to be more likely than the 2017 outlier. But this is a strange year too so it may also end up being a bit of an outlier.
Adding a bit of a pandemic premium. Rationale is from the link below. Thanks to @LokiOdinevich for raising issues with my sloppy thinking.
For the last 3 months of 2020: Bin 1 = <29/month Bin 2 = 29 - <49/month Bin 3 = 49 - <69/month Bin 4 = 69 or more/month

I thought that seasonality was going to be a thing. October came and proved me wrong. A pretty drastic dip would have to happen in order for this year to be below 735; otherwise, both @cafebedouin's less formal and @mikemobbs more formal Bayes calculation point in the same direction. One reason why I'm not higher on the more than 795 bucket is because I may have bad priors. Another reason is that if I ask the question: Will there be more or less murders than in 2016, a 50-50 seems very appealing.
Current total is 576. Years with 550+ at end of September with year totals are listed below. Make of it what you will.

A few days to go still in September and we're at 576. Updating with Bayes gives me 91% for the fourth bin. I think October's numbers will be telling, and I'm prepared to swing fully into the third bin should the numbers shift downward.

Already at 576 for 2020, currently set for 779. Regression to the mean suggests it will likely not increase too much past this mark, but it is difficult to see how we won't hit at least 735 this year with over 3 months remaining. Interestingly, current numbers are nearly identical to those in 2016, which ended with 762 homicides total, further hinting at the ultimate 736-795 outcome. https://www.cnn.com/2017/01/01/us/chicago-murders-2016/index.html

Seasonality story: After looking at seasonality, the crowd forecast seems about right; we had ~100 homicides in the summer months, but ~70 (56 so far) this September. If we see ~50 homicides/month in the winter months, we get 691. Probability implied by this view: 10/80/20/0
Time to ditch my optimism. Nod to @cafebedouin
Increase of 20 to 558 for September. Adjusting inputs to Bayes to update forecast.

Depleting fewer than 676 possibility, appears like probability of that is negligible. In 2017 there were 166 homicides from now until year end. That would put it at 538 + 166 = 704 homicides at the end of the year. I think it's more likely that the lower slopes of previous years is followed than the steeper slope of 2016, which looks like a bit of an outlier. Of course, this year is an outlier as far as major events goes, so low confidence in that.
- Numbers in September (up to 09/10) again increased to around 20% above 2015-2019 average - Data point toward >770
Increasing my very low probabilities a little bit, because I realize I'm not really that well calibrated for low percentages.

Updated to 538 as of September 13, increased probability of surpassing 795 for the year.
My optimism Appears to have been misplaced in near term (538 to date). Regardless still going low.

Current pace puts the total around 773, a significant uptick from historic averages but a forecast well in-line with current trends (no large-scale event driving the totals). A regression to the mean is possible, if unlikely, but given the sustained elevated levels thus far it seems more probable that we end the year comfortably within the 736 and 795 range. I'd guess in the 750s.
539 total as of 11am September 13. Approximate monthly numbers through year end to hit specific bins: >676 = 39 >735 = 56 >795 = 73

However, historical averages predict this year will end closer to 722, which falls well within the second bucket. I lean more towards the historical averages than the current pace, but it appears the other 2 buckets are becoming less likely by the day.

So I was right!!!! I did miscalculate using Bayes Formula in my earlier forecast...... specifically in how I calculated P(B|A), or the probability of at least 485 deaths in August given any of the 4 conditions in the challenge (<676, 676-735, 736-795, >795)....

Based on the Chicago data it looks to me like the killing of George Floyd (on May 25) was the spark for the jump in homicides. That pushed the trend up to a new level, but I think the rest of the year will follow a similar slope as previous years now that time has passed and things may have calmed down a bit. In my opinion the likely range is between 2016 and 2017 looking at the chart at the Chicago Tribune. I'm leaning toward the lower end of that range just based on the last two years and that 2017 looks like it may have been an outlier in the rate of homicides at the tail end of the year.

Upping a little to 736-795 because of current rates placing ultimate total projection around 735. Still believe regression to mean and police crackdowns will lead to lower ultimate rates, but the figures thus far are not reflecting my initial assumptions. Will update in coming weeks.
New stats till Augusts = 440. Same rate = 755 for the year.

I'm using Bayes Formula to calculate this, and I'm sure that I'm off here.... but first, a shout out to @mkamuda for linking me to the historical data going back to 1957, and a thanks to @cafebedouin for providing it.
The push back and defunding of the police coupled with social tensions and mass unemployment due to Covid restrictions make it likely that violence will increase to beyond previously seen levels.
Giving more weight to a regression back to the mean.

This is a really poor forecast, made simply by looking at how the current death toll of 464 compares to the data available at the Chicago Tribune website. I'm quite sure that there is a math driven way to arrive at a reasonable projection.... but that's a project for this week!

With 440 homicides until end of July, that is 2.07 per day for the 213 days of the year so far. We have 153 days remaining in 2020, from end of July. Thus, assuming steady pace of homicides, we can extrapolate to 756 for the year. Having said that, the high pace of the first 7 months of 2020 doesn't necessarily mean it will keep up the same, and could slow down (since it is a high pace, I am less inclined to believe that it could further accelerate, although it might still). A pace of 1.54 homicides per day from Aug 1st onwards is what would be required to get to 676 homicides, which is the divider between the two brackets. This is a pace that is 25% less than the pace of homicides in the year to date. I find that, while the pace can definitely get slower, it will be hard to get to something much slower (e.g. 30% or 40% slower pace). So I tend to believe that the second bracket is more plausible.

There are currently 452 homicides in Chicago for 2020 (https://graphics.suntimes.com/homicides/), meaning the projection is now around 733 homicides for the year, around 7 less than my projection 2 weeks ago. The mean for Chicago has been 675 historically, so the number will likely continue regressing toward the mean for the remainder of the year. Evidence suggests homicides increase around holidays, which we still have quite a few of this year, but those spikes are unlikely to have a notable impact on the overall count. With the federal government now taking an interest in the increasing crime rate and potentially looking to interfere, it is also unlikely the rate will continue of increase by years end. Really, its going to come down to a natural rate towards the years end, and predicting that is going to come down to historic norms, which suggest the second bucket.
first seven months extrpolated = 755 accelerated in july + regression to mean -- issue brought to attention -

In a normal month there are ~50 deaths but covid is causing that to double. However it can't double for the month that have already occured. Since covid is still present in the US and an improvement for the real economy is unlikely for atleast a few months it seems that the higher rate of murders could continue for the rest of this year this giving this prediction.

Crime is up nation wide, it's hard to tell if it is due to the protests, police, or COVID-19. And I am not going to try to parse out that problem at this point and time because they are innumerably linked together. However, it would silly to think that there is not some connection between that group of variables and crime that is happening.

Chicago had 440 Homicides recorded as of July 31st, while during the same period last year there were only 290 homicides, so an increase of 150 or about 50%. In 2016, the most violent recent year, there were 780 homicides, and Chicago has already surpassed them on a YDT basis (440 vs 404).
It has been dropping for the last couple of years, but the pandemic and riots have it on the increase again.
A new president will energize people to do better.
I'm looking at the Chicago homicide dataset (https://data.cityofchicago.org/Public-Safety/Homicides/k9xv-yxzs).

[2] This is the last report that provides detailled statistics for each month. Assuming a similar distribution this means that approximately 800 homicides will happen in 2020 in Chicago, IL.

Let me show my convoluted math. I want to calculate numbers for the remaining 5 months using the assumption the rate will stay the same as it has for June and July but adjusting for seasonal factors, since summer months tend to be worse than cooler months.

Chicago has the highest number of gang members in any city in the US and 80% of murders there are gang related. The gangs are not thought to be only driven by criminal economic activity but act "revolve around identity and solidarity among young people who find themselves in similar circumstances and share an identification with a particular neighbourhood."(3).

Peak months have been May, June & July. There have been 644 deaths in the year ended July 29,2020. Have the most murders so far this CY in past 8 yearsShould be in the 676 range - plus or minus.

The US murder rate is about 5 in 100,000 people, which is around 0.005%. This is equivalent to about 135 deaths in Chicago. However, the murder rate in Chicago is markedly higher, so this will serve as a lower limit. Since 1985, the average murder rate in Chicago is around 25 in 100,000 residents, or about 675 homicides per year. This will serve as a historic mean. The highest rate on record is about 0.33%, or 891 homicides in a single year. At the end of June this year, Chicago was on pace for 658 murders despite a large uptick since last year, where there were a little over 500 for the entire year. As of July 29th, there were 432 murders, putting the projection at 740 for the year. A lot are in the news right now given the federal response, but the surge isn't unprecedented and will likely slow down. Odds are, the year will close out a close to the 676 mark, probably a little higher.
Appreciate commentary from @cafebedouin and @Jayce below.
